Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2009 06:11AM PT63 wrote: Junebug I chose a bilat. mastectomy.  I had many people give me advice not to do it because my cancer was considered relatively small and they thought I was "going overboard".  My breast surgeon explained to me that the survival rate is no different between lumpectomy and mastectomy but the local recurrence rate can be different.  I made my decision based upon the fact that I had already had my children, didn't need my breasts for nursing babies, and didn't feel like I needed that part of me to be "me".  I also didn't want to have radiation and I wanted to decrease my chances of local recurrence. I will tell you though and I am not trying to scare you but I had to have two reconstructions.  My first plastic surgeon was definitely not a perfectionist and the two sides ended up very different.  I had to have a revision done (by a different surgeon) and different implants put in.  Now they look much better and are symmetrical as well as perky.  The down side is that I really don't have much sensation. If you have enough tissue I think you can do a double reconstruction but I doubt if you will be able to get "D"s.  If you look at using your own tissue make sure you find a surgeon that can do DIEPs instead of TRAM flaps.  DIEPs dont use your muscle so you have less chance of other complications later.  Some surgeons have been trained in DIEPs and SGAPs which both use your own tissue.  I feel that If the surgeon is only able to do TRAM flaps I would get another opinion because that would indicate to me that they haven't been keeping up on the latest procedures. One way one of the ladies here said that she found her surgeon was to go to a breast cancer support group and ask the ladies there who they were happy with.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed IDC.............looking at bilat mast. Junebug40 PT63

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2009 06:35PM PT63 wrote: Did you know that you can request an anesthesiologist at some hospitals?  I always have a terrible reaction to anesthesia.  I was talking about it once to my children's pediatrician.  She told me that she actually asked around to find out which anesthesiologist had the least complications during surgery and requested that person when she had her hysterectomy.  She told me the name and I requested that person.  I didn't even know you could do that!  No two anesthesiologists are alike.  Each one likes their own drugs and their own way of doing things.  Ask around before your next surgery especially since it is a long one. Take good care

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2009 06:30PM PT63 wrote: Congrats. on the Path Report! Talk to your breast oncologist about the benefits vs. side effects of Tamox. vs. AI.  I had a complete hysterectomy/ooph. and am staying on Tamox. for now because the first year after menopause is when the greatest bone loss occurs and Tamox. actually helps protect your bones.  If I remember correctly the AIs make your bone density worse.  There are some new studies out about taking Tamox. then changing to AIs.  I think the results are promising but your onc. would probably know the statistics better than I would.  My gyn/onc also wanted me to stay on Tamox. but I think his concern was the bone loss and the fact that Tamox. is a proven drug.  It has been on the market forever!
Posts.Title: Ooph recovery help !! jackiebrown mradf

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2009 03:44PM PT63 wrote: Karen I totally agree with you.  Everyone has to make the decisions that they can live with.  I had my Oncotype when the test was relatively new.  I got two differing opinions from two different oncologists which I have written about in a different thread.  I chose the one I could live with.  I also did not believe in throwing everything at it, if "everything" wasn't going to make a statistically significant difference. I didn't mention it in the earlier post but I chose the hysterectomy for two reasons....one was because of the Tamoxifen/fibroid growth and the other was because my mom was diagnosed with ovarian cancer the year before I was diagnosed with BC.  I decided since I was using those particular parts any more, I would just have them removed before they caused me any more problems. Best of luck to you
Posts.Title: Anyone declining further treatment after bilateral? karen_3 Jamie6

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2009 06:17PM PT63 wrote: Karen I believe that after your initial surgery there will be no reason to rush into a treatment that you are not comfortable with.  My advice would be to get your tumor tissue retested by another pathologist so that you are comfortable with the pathology results.  I would also get another opinion from another oncologist (or two) in another facility (or two).  Sometimes the second oncologist will request the tissue retest - this is what happened in my case.  The oncologist wanted the tissue to be re-tested in their hospital laboratory because they wanted to make sure that they were making an appropriate recommendation. In addition, in my case the Oncotype DX test was not covered by my insurance.  It is a $3000 plus test - at least it was 2 years ago.  I did get some of the cost "forgiven" but it was still quite costly.  If you are not in the gray area that the Oncotype is developed for,  you may be spending a lot of money for no additional information. In my case I was so freaked out about having cancer that I wanted all my tests and surgeries done yesterday or the day before.  But in your case if you are thinking of declining additional treatment anyway, you have plenty of time to get more information.  If you change your mind within a short time after surgery, there most likely will not be a significant effect on the outcome of the treatment plan. If you don't respect the opinion of the oncologist that you have already seen, you probably should not continue with that person.  You will most likely see your oncologist for YEARS of follow up after this diagnosis so you may want to find one that you trust. Sending you bc sisterly love....

Posts.Title: path question tam1953 LizM

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2009 05:59AM PT63 wrote: Karen The bilateral will reduce your risk for "local" recurrence but does not do anything for the little micro-cells that may have already escaped into your systemic circulation.  Given the size of your tumor, it could indicate one of two things: either it is slow growing and has been growing for a long time, or you have an aggressive form and it is growing rather quickly.  The information on your pathology report that would indicate this is your "grade" of tumor.  Grade 1= slow, Grade 2=moderate, Grade 3 = aggressive.  In addition you are both ER+ and Her2+ - both which indicate that there are other options for you besides chemo which on these discussion boards is considered a "lucky" thing.  I also agree with revkat.  Your oncotype score will mean nothing if you choose not to take Tamoxifen because that is factored into the statistics. I had a bilat. 12/30/06 at age 43.  My Oncotype score was 13.  I did not have to have chemo or radiation but I was ER+ (90%) so I chose to have Tamox.  I had no side effects on Tamox. except for significant growth of uterine fibroids - caught on routine sonogram- not because of side effects that I noticed.  Since Tamox. gives a higher risk of uterine cancer (not cervical), and I was so estrogen sensitive, I chose to have a hysterect/oopherectomy at age 45. Tamox. is not a hormone.  It is a SERM - selective estrogen receptor modulator.  It binds to your free-estrogen so that it is not available to effect other organs.  It is also offers mild protection from bone loss - which is good for those of us over 40.  Tamox. has been around a very very very long time and has a good track record.  Since I am not HER2+, I have not done any research on Herceptin.  But there are many who believe that are still here because of it. There are no guarantees for any treatment but please don't discount your options until you have all the information available presented to you.
Posts.Title: Anyone declining further treatment after bilateral? karen_3 Jamie6

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2009 07:47PM PT63 wrote: Karen Maybe I can help you look at this from a different perspective.  Let's say there is no "cure" for some forms/types of breast cancer just like there is no "cure" for diabetes, lupus or multiple sclerosis.  BUT there are treatments available that address all these disease processes like a long term or chronic illness.  A diabetic takes insulin to keep their diabetes under control or suffers dire consequences, and in the end most severe diabetics die from complications due to their diabetes.  The length of time a diabetic lives after original diagnosis and the complications they incur is dependent on the efficacy of treatment and the "brittleness" of the diabetes.  No two diabetics are alike, so no two treatment regimines are alike.  People with lupus and multiple sclerosis take steroids and other chemo type drugs to decrease inflammation and complications associated with their disease processes.  Both are autoimmune diseases and the symptoms are unique to each individual who is diagnosed.  Each person responds differently to treatment and the progression of the disease is dependent on the treatment and response. Cancer can also be treated like a chronic illness.  You can start by treating it aggressively when first diagnosed or you can wait and see.  If you wait and see, you may not have any recurrence and no further treatment may be necessary.  But if you wait and see, and your symptoms change including a recurrence or mets then your options for treatment will change accordingly - your options will not necessarily be the same ones you have now because your disease will be different.  In my view and my case, Tamoxifen is part of a long term treatment of a chronic illness.  Once I am finished with Tamoxifen (and maybe before), there will be nothing inhibiting my estrogen receptors and I may have a recurrence.  BUT it is my hope that by taking the Tamox. I will have at least 5 extra years of NED and hopefully those little estrogen fed cancer cells will starve and never come back!  At the very least my children will be 5 years older and more ready to face the world.  If I have a recurrence when this treatment is over, I will face new choices.  I am lucky in that I can tolerate my current treatment without difficulty.  I know that is not the case for all and other choices need to be made. Good luck with your decisions

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2007 02:30AM PT63 wrote: I had a bilateral mastectomy with bilateral sentinel node biopsies. Didn't know it was going to cause me so much hassle. The oncologist's office takes my BP in my leg. This hurts like you wouldn't believe especially if you have vericose veins. It also gives falsely elevated readings as compared to your arms. I have never ever had high BP and the leg reading put me in the abnormal range. They told me that they were not concerned because it was from the leg. If that is the case, then what information are they getting from it? I am not planning on having it done any more as a routine procedure.

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2009 09:06PM PT63 wrote: In reality, even the "Not diagnosed but Worried" posters have to be very careful about answering questions from those who are worried about getting the initial diagnosis.  Really all we can say is "I'm sorry you are worried, I am sorry you have those symptoms.... if I were you I would go see a PCP/Oncologist/Lymphedema Specialist/Breast Surgeon/Radiologist etc etc etc".  But because there is a seperate forum very few of the undiagnosed jump into a different one, so those of us who have the diagnosis can visit them/that forum when we feel the urge to give advice. This forum is a more select audience who are highly active on the boards.  The first response of the already diagnosed may be "Let me ask someone who has gone through it". But I truly understand why some of the questions would annoy especially if as jeanne says that you have your own questions of the day.  So I still think having a "Is this mets" forum would allow those who are worried post those questions.  And then those who want to answer can say:  "I'm sorry you are worried, I am sorry you have those symptoms.... if I were you I would go see your Oncologist/Lymphedema Specialist/Breast Surgeon/Radiologist/PCP etc etc etc. " Because really what else can one say?  We can't order the scans or tests for anyone. There will always be those who post here by error.  But I think once people are redirected a few times it will become clear to those who read these boards where the appropriate forum is.  Then I would hope that the frequency would decrease. Although I hope I haven't posted anything overtly stupid on this forum, I do read the posts here and on the hospice/palliative care forums.  I value the stories and comments that I read and I have gotten a lot of useful information.  I recently lost one of my dearest friends to bc.  She was in complete denial that she had mets and she had convinced herself and her pcp that she had lymes disease. (long story) She waited a very long time to have a complete work up and I believe that it may have contributed to her rapid decline.  I think that if she would have asked her questions to those who post here someone would have said.."Go see your oncologist!!!!!!" and maybe she would have benefitted from earlier treatment.  As it was she did not want to "scare" me since I am more recently diagnosed.  When she finally told me her symptoms I said "Go see your oncologist!!!!!"  Needless to say, she did not have Lymes. If people think that a different forum for these questions would be helpful how would that come about?

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2009 10:53PM PT63 wrote: I am not trying to defend physicians that chronically overbook and run late but sometimes it is the sign of a caring physician.  My gynecological-oncologist runs incredibly behind.  BUT he is awesome.  Once you are in the room with him it seems like you are the only person in the world he cares about.  If you have an infected stitch or think something is horribly wrong he squeezes you into the schedule.  You may wait 3 hours if you are the one who is squeezed in, but no question is too stupid for him.  He actually once called me back from his personal cell phone at 10PM. I always book my appointment for the first thing in the morning.  He starts at 7:30AM and I always book that appointment.  His wife now works in the office because she sees him on their commute to work together and on their way home. There are physicians who overbook because of financial incentives and I agree that those people should really re-think their office management.  But if you are feeling charitable, try to see if it is because of poor management or truly caring about each person.

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2009 09:46PM PT63 wrote: Hi Jpixstix Sorry you are having so much pain.  I can tell you that after my bilat. mx with TEs I had drains in for 3 weeks so I couldn't do much either.  After the drains were out I made an appointment with a PT that was certified in lymphedema.  She went over some exercises that would ensure that I would regain full range of motion and she also went over precautions for ex. etc.  I had more problems with pain on my left side where the tumor was.  I thought it was all in my head but the PT told me that she could actually feel the edge of the expander and thought that may be causing my pain.  It will get better with time....if it doesn't make sure you make an appointment with your PS.
Posts.Title: bil/mas with t/e, when will I feel comfortable again? jpixstix JanMarch

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2009 07:15AM - edited Mar 26, 2009 07:20AM by PT63 Good Morning I had surgery on Friday and was home by noon on Saturday.  I had my surgery the friday before a holiday weekend so I think they were definitely promoting my leaving but my insurance had authorized 2 nights so I could have stayed if I wanted.  I had a friend who stayed overnight in the hospital with me.  She is a nurse and said that she could not leave me even though I encouraged her to go.  It was actually kind of nice to have her there since it was a little harder to move my arms at first.  By the morning I could move all body parts, walk, go to the bathroom etc so I went home.  I slept in a recliner for the first week at home. The first week was a little difficult because of the drains and taking a shower.  I actually went to a hair salon the third day home so they could wash and blow dry my hair because I wanted to feel "normal".  You also will have lifting restrictions and it is amazing how heavy that neighborly pan of lasagna is!  I made several meals ahead of time.  If I had to do it over I would have put them in foil pans not my heavy glass baking dishes.  I was driving fairly quickly (7 days?) but it is a strange feeling when you have to crank the steering wheel.  I also have a van and kept forgetting that it was the closing of the back door that was the hard part - reaching overhead and pulling down...I forgot initially and had to ask a stranger in the grocery store parking lot to do it for me.  It is also amazing how heavy the double doors to the doctor's office are! My children were pre-teens at the time so they were very helpful but don't turn down any offers from neighbors or friends.  Children tend to lose focus on the "helpful" part fairly quickly and want to know when you are going to be cleared to vacuum again! Best of luck to you...
Posts.Title: How long was your Hosp stay for BLMas LynnVA NancyD

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2009 12:06PM PT63 wrote: Hi Red I didn't have any rawness under my actual armpits but the drains were placed pretty far to the sides.  I had my drains in for 3 weeks and they did get a little irritated around the incision site by the end of that time.  If I remember right I actually think I asked the doctor if I could use some moisturizer/vaseline to keep the hole area moist so it didn't look so inflamed. Are the drains supported?  I had these little bags that attached to my mastectomy bra that the drains went in.  It kept them from hanging and annoying the skin area even more. It didn't actually hurt when the drains were pulled out but it is a really strange feeling.  You may want to take something before you go in that day if you are worried. Take good care
Posts.Title: bil/mas with t/e, when will I feel comfortable again? jpixstix JanMarch

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2010 03:59PM PT63 wrote: zil, I agree with Ruthbru.  I saw my oncologist every 3 months for the 1st year and every 6 months after that.  My treatment and yours are similar.  Sometimes I think it is a little crazy to go there because there is really nothing to look at.  But they insist that I come every 6 months for a face to face visit. msqueen I found my current oncologist through word of mouth.  I had a very bad experience with my initial visit to a different oncologist even though the practice came highly recommended by my surgeon - he just wasn't for me.  And truthfully you get to see your oncologist for a very very long time so you really need to at least trust them and feel like they have your best interests in mind.  After I hated the first practice I asked around to friends or friends of friends who had unfortunately had the same diagnosis.  The local hospital also has a breast cancer support group which would have been a good resource had I not found an oncologist I liked through people in my neighborhood. carcharm My oncologist asks me to have all of my blood work done through my internists office and then have it faxed to her.  She recommended the blood work to be done every year since I am on Tamox. - more often if I have symptoms.  I also had a bone density study done through my internist.  But as I said before I still get checked by the oncologist every 6 months and I have BC/BS for insurance.
